awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Photocatalytic Water Purification Technology for the Removal of Pollutants that  are Commonly Problematic for Water Treatment Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is an improvement in the current state-of-the-art water purification capability. The technology expands the range of water purification effectiveness and provides a means of preventing anthropogenic wastes from entering the environment through photocatalytic degradation. The removal of organic material from the water system has an ever-increasing role in the subject of human health. The degree to which anthropogenic water waste affects human health is ultimately tied to the ability to remove these wastes from our water supply. Unlike filtration methods, photocatalytic oxidation has the ability to destroy these contaminants without the need for chemical additives. Successful commercialization of this technology protects health by improving the capability for organic waste remediation. There also are many industrial applications requiring organic pollutant removal where this technology can have impact. The proposed system is capable of oxidizing water contaminants and can destroy contaminants that are commonly problematic for water treatment systems. 

This I-Corps project is based on fundamental research showing improved efficiency and scalability of photocatalytic water purification systems by optimizing the 3D geometry of the catalyst material in conjunction with the geometry of the illumination system. The result was a significant reduction in energy loss, as well as an overall improved usability and scalability of the system. The photocatalyst material itself also has been modified in order to optimize the electrical and chemical properties of the catalyst surface. Implantation of TiO2 and SiO2 nanoparticles resulted in increased degradation performance by more than 500%. The overall efficiency of the photocatalytic reactor also was considered with respect to energy usage as defined by the Electrical Energy per Order (EEO) characterization model. The lowest EEO achieved in this system was 54 kWh per cubic meter of water for each order of magnitude reduction in pollutant concentration - an improvement in EEO over previously reported thin-film based photoreactors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The primary goal of this project was to establish a product-market fit for our water purification technology through customer discovery research. Our technology, based on a light-activated catalyst, destroys water pollutants without the addition of chemicals. The I-Corps Teams program allowed us to explore the water purification marketplace to better understand the limitations of existing technologies and to find where gaps may occur in their application. 


Our team conducted 124 in-person interviews over the project period. During this process, we quickly found that our original target market, ultrapure water production, was not viable for photocatalytic systems. This led us to explore several other possibilities including home purification systems and PFAS (polyfluoroalkyl substance) remediation. 


Ultimately, we determined that the successful commercialization of photocatalyst materials has the potential to improve the wastewater treatment process by reducing the energy consumption of the Advanced Oxidation stage. This can be particularly impactful in municipal water recycling applications because of the increased motivation to remove trace organic substances, such as pharmaceuticals.


We then sought to clarify our value proposition as existing water purification systems are already highly effective at water refinement. We found that a primary challenge in this market includes the high energy consumption of the UV bulbs in existing Advanced Oxidation systems as well as poor removal rates for a number of trace organic contaminants. Our objective has thus moved on to investigating these weaknesses and determining where our system can outperform the competition. 


This project also gave us the opportunity to refine our prototype system to meet the needs of the water recycling process. In order to increase the flow rate of our system, we utilized Finite Element Analysis (FEA) and Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD) to reduce the resistance of our connections and increase the strength of our catalyst material. These changes allow us to scale up our design to the high pressure and high flow requirements of a municipal system.


Overall, we found that the I-Corps Teams program was exceptionally helpful in adapting our technology to the existing water purification marketplace. We found our original concept of the market, which was based on academic review and analysis, was lacking of crucial real-world details. Therefore, further research and development for our technique are needed in order to transfer it to the market place. In summary, getting out of the lab to do in-person interviews in the field transformed our approach and drastically improved the applicability of our technology. 


 

 


Last Modified: 06/21/2021
Modified by: Jun Jiao
